oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hyperkaluria as a Risk Factor for Periparturient Paresis in Dairy Cows: Case Study of a Herd without a Hypocalcemia Prevention Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eicher, R.
Settler, M.
Tschudi, P.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: hypocalcemia
dietary calcium
anionic diets
milk fever
potassium content
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Periparturient hypocalcemia is one of the main metabolic challenges in dairy cows. Traditionally, high dietary calcium during the dry period was hypothesized to be the major risk factor for periparturient paresis. However, recent research has shown that metabolic alkalosis induced by high potassium in the diet plays a major role in the development of parturient hypocalcemia 1. Therefore, anionic diets are increasingly being used in practice to prevent milk fever. In rations based on forages with high potassium content, anionic diets are problematic because of the quantity of anionic salts needed, leading to a reduction of dry matter intake. The following case report illustrates the influence of a high potassium load on the incidence of milk fever in a herd without a prevention program for periparturient hypocalcemia.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2002; 271
